text: almost four months into the mission
curiosity finally reaches Yellowknife
Bay a possible ancient Lake bet five
hundred yards from where she landed we
rolled down into Yellowknife Bay we
realized we had found something really
good we looked around and we saw this
kind of a rock that was fractured and
had veins in it we've got a lot of
evidence for water here with its laser
curiosity's apps one of the veins and
from the puff of smoke can see that this
is a mineral with water inside and it
was just one more piece of story that
says there's a history of water here and
where there's water there's a potential
for life curiosity's drill is a crucial
but potentially dangerous tool every
time we take the robotic arm and put it
in contact with the surface of Mars we
all get a little nervous because the
last thing in the world you want to do
is and have the rover slip a little bit
and break something on the arm break an
instrument off break one of the joints
and doing a drilling operation is just
that even more so because you're now
putting this drill bit into a hole where
if the rover moves at all you have the
likelihood of jamming that bit or
snapping that bit off yeah I worry about
it a lot
another month goes by then finally
they're ready to drill and find out what
this rock reveals about the story of
life on Mars we drilled and it was
amazing we drilled this rock and when
the powder came up and powder was gray
it had sort of the greyish greenish
color we're so used to seeing rad rocks
everywhere suggesting everything is
oxidized to this rusty iron color not a
good place for organics you know when
you oxidize you and rust you also
oxidize the organic sawai and that was
our first indication that not everything
is oxidized on Mars these rocks have
something else going on in them it was
sort of like this window opens and we
knew that some of this record that were
after has been preserved first they
analyzed the powder to see what the rock
is made of and when it came back it
shocked us we've got the clean mother
lode this is 20% clays and the great
thing about clay it's not acidic it's
not some extreme environment and you're
looking at this thing and it could have
been a freshwater lake this is one of
the things they came looking for a place
